Campus. Electoral Majority Shifts To Roosevelt
Late Returns
From New York
GiveF.D.R.Lead
83,560 Students Vote In Nation-Wide Collegiate
Poll
C. C. N. Y. Changes Result
Roosevelt Leads Landon By
Plurality Of Over
5,000
Last minute returns on a straw vote
held at the City College of New York
completely upset the previous results
of the nation-wide collegiate Presidential poll conducted by the Daily
Prineetonian. The City College poll
gave President Roosevelt, candidate of
the Democratic party, a sufficiently
large majority to enable him to overcome a small lead held by Governor
Alf M. Landon in New York State up
to the time of the final returns. This
switched the electoral vote of the
state, with 47 votes to Roosevelt,
giving him a total collegiate electoral
vote of 253 to 186 for his opponent.
The final returns now show that a
total of 83,560 votes were cast, Roosevelt leading with 40,914, having a
majority of over 5,000 votes over his
nearest opponent, Governor Landon,
who received 35,835 ballots. Earl
Browder, Communist, with 2733, Norman Thomas, Socialist, with 828, and
Lemke, Union Party, with 1.115 votes,
bring up in the rear.
The C.C.N.Y. poll, conducted by
The Campus, undergraduate publication at that institution, was participated in by 2962 students. Roosevelt
received 1937 votes, Landon, 3127,
Browder, 590, and Thomas, 308. In
New York State before the City College poll results came in, Landon had
been in the lead by 3102 votes to
Roosevelt's 3026. The latter's great
gain in the City College vote, however,
easily overcame this small deficit and
won for himself the 47 electoral votes.
The national poll included 93 higher
institutions of learning in 34 of the 48
states. The two leading candidates
each won out in 17, or one half, of the
states included in the poll.
Roosevelt was victor in the following states: Alabama, California, Illinois, Iowa, Kentucky, Michigan, Montant Nebraska, Nevada, New York,
North Carolina, Oklahoma, Tennessee,
Texas Virginia Washington, and Wisconsin.
Landon led in these states: Colorado,
Connecticut, Delaware, Idaho,Indiana,
Kansas, Maine, Maryland„ Massachusetts, Missouri, New Hampshire, New
Jersey, Ohio, Pennsylvania Rhode Island, Vermont, West Virginia.
The 14 states which did not participate in the vote were Arizona, Arkansas, Florida, Georgia, Louisiana,
Minnesota, Mississippi, North Dakota,
New Mexico, Oregon, South Carolina,
South Dakota, Utah Wyoming.

el.S.U. Resolves To
Extend Greetings To
Spanish Government
At their meeting held Thursday,
October 29, the American Student
Union adopted a resolution to extend greetings to the Spanish government. Their resolution follows:
"VV;e the members of the
American Student Union, together with others of the student body of the Johns Hopkins University, extend greetings and express solidarity
with our fellow students and
other defenders of the democratic and duly elected Spanish
government."
The meeting was marked by an
address given by Dr. Blumberg of
the Philosophy Department. In it
he described the sivation in Spain.

Publication of Calendar
The inauguration of the publication of a weekly calendar by the
University took place yesterday as
ember 2 was mailed to the members of the faculty and placed on
many of the bulletin boards in the
various buildings.

Regional"Y."Head
Tells Of Chinese
Political Situation

tion is in progress which will make it
possible for one to board a train at
Hong Kong and go straight through
to Paris, without getting off the train.
Industrially and ariculturally, new
developments are constantly being
made. There are over 38,000 cooperative farming groups in China with a
membership of over 200,000 farmers.
The land which has been destroyed
by Communist revolts is being rehabilitated and the work is being directed
by prominent engineers in every field.
Dr. Munsen, who is a graduate of
Grinnel College, has been working in
China since 1910, and has been responsible for a •great part of the
YMCA's work there.

Engineering Student
Escapes From Flame
.Overcome By Fumes When Gasoline
Stove In Trailer
Explodes
John S. Wright, a senior in the Engineering School at Johns Hopkins
University, narrowly escaped serious
injury yesterday when the automobile
trailer serving as his home was destroyed by the flames of a fire started
as the gasoline stove in which he
was preparing his supper exploded.

Correction
Due to an unfortunate error, the
date of the engagement of the
aHedgerow Players' was reported
for November 19.
The Hedgerow Players will be
seen in two plays at the Auditorium Theatre, afternoon and evening, on Wednesday, November 18.

Debating Council Meeting
Announced By Grossman
A meeting of the debating council
will be held next Thursday in Gilman
205, it was announced by Phillip Grossman, recently elected head of the varsity orators. Among Grossman's varsity teammates this year are Brown,
Macht, and Moss, all of whom starred
in intercollegiate contests in 1935-36.
Besides these veterans there is expected a turnout of fresh material in
th form of Frosh aspirants to the
team.

One-hundred twenty-nine seniors,
approximately three-fourths of the
class, voted last Friday in the finals
of the Senior elections that the administration of the class will be undertaken by five men representing both
the A.B. and engineering schools. This
group was led by Roy Galloway,
elected president by a close margin
over John Himes.. Neither of the candidates for the presidency had ever attempted to gain class office before.

Intensive Research On Fraternity Methods Goes For
Naught As Frosh Forget To Memorize
Chapter Names
It happened at one of the fraternities last week.
All the pledgees were notified by
ominous inference and sly innuendoes
that they could expect a "Hell Night"
soon. On that evening they would be
required to recite the names of the
various Chapters of the fraternity
together with their affiliated universities, and would be expected to "do
a few odd jobs for the fellows." With
the inevitability of a "life-worse-thaneath" confronting them, the poor
freshmen spent most of the week in
a blue "funk." They worried and
sweated themselves into frenzies trying to predict what might possibly be
in store for them, and spent many
sleepless hours tossing in beds which
had no welcome for Morpheus. With
every waking moment they strived
to circumvent by such methods as
they could, the diabolical designs of
the fraters. Finally, all the pledgees
got together in working out a plan
which had possibilities of acheiving
their purpose.

Seniors Asked To
Pose This Week
Photos Of Seniors Made This Week
Only; Special Offer Made By
Photographer
"It is absolutely essential that students keep their appointments for
Hullabaloo photographs. Failure to
do this will necessitate curtailment of
features." This warning was given
yesterday by Robert Austrian, editorin-chief of the Hullabaloo, along with
the notices to Seniors to report to
have their pictures taken. Those who
have not received their appointments
should report to the yearbook office
immediately so as to be sure of being
Included.
A special offer is being extended for
this week only by the photographer of
1 dozen 2 x 3 fylor $2, or 1 dozen 3 x 5
for $2. This offer is open to all students who are having pictures made
for the book. Everyone is urged to
take advantage of this opportunity.
The photos will be taken of the
Seniors this week only. It is for this
reason that it is necessary for prompt
arrival and payment, as the charge of
$1 is made with the photo.

among the manuscripts of the Huntington Library collection, in California.
Dr. Heltzel was also instrumental in
the translating of the document from
the original Latin form, and it was
with his permission that Dr. Hudson
addressed the group.
The manuscript wai written just
after Sidney's death during the English Renaissance by a London medical
doctor and Latin scholar, one Dr. Moffet. It was not written as a biography
but rather as an object lesson from
the man who wrote it to his young
nephew, Wm. Henry, later the Earl of
Pembroke, who was at the time just
entering Oxford, at the age of 14.
The manuscript is very important as
it contains the greatest praise ever
heaped on Sidney, and also gives many
details of his early life and of his fighting in Flanders, where he died, heretofore unknown. It especially commends
his valor in battle, holding him up
as a paragon of virtue and courage.
Although they wish to make this
valuable literature public, neither Dr.
Hudson nor his associate are yet satisfied with the Latin translation they
have made. After revision is made,
the document will be ready for publication.

pushed over four well-earned touchdowns, thereby pulling out of what
was a disastrous slump.
Speed Too Much
The Blue Jays, despite their determination to maintain a perfect record against their erst-while foes,
could not cope with the speed of the
Randalph-Macon backfield. Their line
play around the center was practically
air-tight, but the visting team elected
to direct its attack around the ends.
However, it took a system of tricky
laterals, and some well-nigh perfect
blocking to make this offensive successful.
The Virginians' scoring was concentrated in the third and early fourth
quarters. "Baby" Bair's 65-yard demonstration of broken - field running
was the outstanding event of the
afternoon. Paliscak, who scored three
touchdowns, was the visiting team's
star.
Graziano Scores
Hopkins' only score came underway in the fourth period with Kahl
and Graziano doing all of the balltoting. Graziano veritably hurled himself across from the 1-yard line.
Randolph-Macon lost no time in
taking the opening Hopkins' kick-off
and driving the Jays back to their own
goal line. In the shadow of their
goal posts, the Blue team tightened
its defense and held for downs. Again
the Yellow-Jackets plowed ahead only
to be denied once more by inspired
resistance on the part of the Jays'
forward wall.
Randolph-Macon Tallies
But when the Jays kicked out of
danger, a lateraled runback set the
stage for the first tally for RandolphMacon. A sustained running and
passing attack earned the Jackets
their first six points. Poliscak hitting
the line for the score. The placement
was wide. The remainder of the first
quarter saw the Blue Jays fighting
hard to push over a touchdown and
being checked by an unpenetrable
visiting line.
The second period brought renewed hopes to the home-team rooters.
After dominating the play for a short
while, the Virginians were forced to
kick, the ball bouncing over the Hopkins goal line for a touchback. Taking
the ball on their own 20-yard line,
the Jays moved fifty yards in a sustained drive, with Graziano and Kahl
carrying the ball off tackle and around
the ends. The Blue line opened up
large holes for the backs to charge
through. But Randolph-Macon finally held for downs on their own 30yard line. The half ended with the
Yellow Jackets in possession of the
ball at midfield.
Jay Strategy Fails
The second half was all RandolphMacon. To start things, instead of
punting on fourth down while on
their own 30-yard line, Hopkins chose
to run the ball in an attempt to gain
a first down. This strategy failed,
and the visitors tok the ball on their
opponent's 30. From here the YellowJackets pushed to a first-down on the
20-yard marker, from which point
Paliscak again crossed the goal line.
The placement this time was good,
and the score stood at 13-0.
Randolph-Macon kickied off and
for a while it looked as if the hometeam were marching to a touchdown.
But once again the visitors tightened.
Bair and Paliscak combined their
running skill to add six more ponts
to their team's total. Paliscak again
bucked the line for the tally. The
conversion attempt failed. The score
stood 19-0.
Early in the last stanza, Greer
punted from deep in his own territory
to the Randolph-Macon 35-yard line.
Bair caught the ball and ran 65 yards

Johnnies Bag
Fourth In Row

The Blue Jay booters battled the
Towson Teachers to a scoreless tie
at Homewood last Friday.
Hopkins came close to a victory
when Bill Gough, playing right half
for the Jays, drew a penalty kick after
a foul by Towson. His boot struck
Goalie Hamilton and the ball bounded back into the playing field. Gough
followed up with another boot which
went into the goal. The referee, however, blew his whistle, after the goal
had been kicked, ruled that the period had ended just after the foul
kick and refused to allow the goal.
Despite the heavy winds that prevailed throughout the game, Clisham,
Jay full back, displayed some outstanding booting. His counter-wind
kicks carried with them the speed and
precision so peculiar to the professional back. Time and again, his welldirected punts had all but dented the
net only to be thwarted by the timely
interception of Goalie Hamilton.
Cecil Kephart, substituting at half
back for Phillips, who in turn was
shifted to the line, also is due worthy
praise for his successful humbling of
Smith, outstanding player for the
Towson Teachers in their previous
meet with the Blue Jays. According
to spectators, he literally "tied him
in a knot." Kephart played the "Towson Threat" close to the line and
never once yielded to his driving onslaught to force the ball into the center of the playing field.

The lack of scoring punch still persisted, however, and aside from the
disputed goal, the Jays were unable to
score.
The most serious set-back to the
Blue "Jays predicted progress this
season, has been the injuries suffered
by several of the more outstanding
performers.
Phillips, left half back and the most
outstanding performer of last season, has been suffering with a bad
ankle ever since the first scrimmage
this year. Bernheim, captain and
right full back, was making repid
strides as a defense performer when
he suffered a muscle injury to his
right leg. Briggs, center forward,
who as a newcome to the Johns Hopkins team, gave a convincing exhibition of offensive play, also is suffering -from a leg injury.
Coach Frank Dotterweich, however,
believes these handicaps will be overcome when the Hopkins entertains the
Blue Ridge Rooters at Homewood,
Saturday at 2.30 o'clock.
Although relatively little is known
concerning the booting ability of the
Mountaineers, nevertheless Coach
Dotterweich will strengthen his offensive line to the limit in order to
assure himself of a quick victory.
Kephart, as a reward for his -brilliant performance in Friday's game,
will share opening honors in the coming tilt.

Entered Hopkins as freshman in
'99 . . . While a student, he was instrumental in building up lacrosse
--in it's embryo form at Hopkins at
the time . . . played five years of varsity lacrosse--the last year as first
year man at the Medical School . . .
Was made a special ex-captain to the
four year rule which was just inaugurated in his senior year . . .
As youngster, played first lacrosse
game as fill-in at center for B.A.C.
to which team he was mascot . . .
Also, played sandlot football with
"Old Parks," together with Arthur
and Philip Poole of Princeton fame.
At Hopkins played ace hockey and
ran in the first relay team to beat
Penn . . . Also copped gymnastic
championship of University for two
years. . . .
Dr. Abercrombie, was President of
his Senior Class and likewise of the
Athletic Board in which he played a
important role in the organization of
the Athletic Association. . .
At present Dr. Abercrombie is the
Director of the University Physical
Education Department at which he
has become a well known campus
personality.

Campus. Electoral Majority Shifts To Roosevelt
Late Returns
From New York
GiveF.D.R.Lead
83,560 Students Vote In Nation-Wide Collegiate
Poll
C. C. N. Y. Changes Result
Roosevelt Leads Landon By
Plurality Of Over
5,000
Last minute returns on a straw vote
held at the City College of New York
completely upset the previous results
of the nation-wide collegiate Presidential poll conducted by the Daily
Prineetonian. The City College poll
gave President Roosevelt, candidate of
the Democratic party, a sufficiently
large majority to enable him to overcome a small lead held by Governor
Alf M. Landon in New York State up
to the time of the final returns. This
switched the electoral vote of the
state, with 47 votes to Roosevelt,
giving him a total collegiate electoral
vote of 253 to 186 for his opponent.
The final returns now show that a
total of 83,560 votes were cast, Roosevelt leading with 40,914, having a
majority of over 5,000 votes over his
nearest opponent, Governor Landon,
who received 35,835 ballots. Earl
Browder, Communist, with 2733, Norman Thomas, Socialist, with 828, and
Lemke, Union Party, with 1.115 votes,
bring up in the rear.
The C.C.N.Y. poll, conducted by
The Campus, undergraduate publication at that institution, was participated in by 2962 students. Roosevelt
received 1937 votes, Landon, 3127,
Browder, 590, and Thomas, 308. In
New York State before the City College poll results came in, Landon had
been in the lead by 3102 votes to
Roosevelt's 3026. The latter's great
gain in the City College vote, however,
easily overcame this small deficit and
won for himself the 47 electoral votes.
The national poll included 93 higher
institutions of learning in 34 of the 48
states. The two leading candidates
each won out in 17, or one half, of the
states included in the poll.
Roosevelt was victor in the following states: Alabama, California, Illinois, Iowa, Kentucky, Michigan, Montant Nebraska, Nevada, New York,
North Carolina, Oklahoma, Tennessee,
Texas Virginia Washington, and Wisconsin.
Landon led in these states: Colorado,
Connecticut, Delaware, Idaho,Indiana,
Kansas, Maine, Maryland„ Massachusetts, Missouri, New Hampshire, New
Jersey, Ohio, Pennsylvania Rhode Island, Vermont, West Virginia.
The 14 states which did not participate in the vote were Arizona, Arkansas, Florida, Georgia, Louisiana,
Minnesota, Mississippi, North Dakota,
New Mexico, Oregon, South Carolina,
South Dakota, Utah Wyoming.

At their meeting held Thursday,
October 29, the American Student
Union adopted a resolution to extend greetings to the Spanish government. Their resolution follows:
"VV;e the members of the
American Student Union, together with others of the student body of the Johns Hopkins University, extend greetings and express solidarity
with our fellow students and
other defenders of the democratic and duly elected Spanish
government."
The meeting was marked by an
address given by Dr. Blumberg of
the Philosophy Department. In it
he described the sivation in Spain.

Tells Of Chinese
Political Situation

tion is in progress which will make it
possible for one to board a train at
Hong Kong and go straight through
to Paris, without getting off the train.
Industrially and ariculturally, new

made. There are over 38,000 cooperative farming groups in China with a

Engineering Student
Escapes From Flame
.Overcome By Fumes When Gasoline
Stove In Trailer
Explodes
John S. Wright, a senior in the Engineering School at Johns Hopkins
University, narrowly escaped serious
injury yesterday when the automobile
trailer serving as his home was destroyed by the flames of a fire started
as the gasoline stove in which he
was preparing his supper exploded.

It happened at one of the fraternities last week.
All the pledgees were notified by
ominous inference and sly innuendoes
that they could expect a "Hell Night"
soon. On that evening they would be
required to recite the names of the
various Chapters of the fraternity
together with their affiliated universities, and would be expected to "do
a few odd jobs for the fellows." With
the inevitability of a "life-worse-thaneath" confronting them, the poor
freshmen spent most of the week in
a blue "funk." They worried and
sweated themselves into frenzies trying to predict what might possibly be
in store for them, and spent many
sleepless hours tossing in beds which
had no welcome for Morpheus. With
every waking moment they strived
to circumvent by such methods as
they could, the diabolical designs of
the fraters. Finally, all the pledgees
got together in working out a plan
which had possibilities of acheiving
their purpose.

Seniors Asked To
Pose This Week
Photos Of Seniors Made This Week
Only; Special Offer Made By
Photographer
"It is absolutely essential that students keep their appointments for
Hullabaloo photographs. Failure to
do this will necessitate curtailment of
features." This warning was given
yesterday by Robert Austrian, editorin-chief of the Hullabaloo, along with
the notices to Seniors to report to
have their pictures taken. Those who
have not received their appointments
should report to the yearbook office
immediately so as to be sure of being
Included.
A special offer is being extended for
this week only by the photographer of
1 dozen 2 x 3 fylor $2, or 1 dozen 3 x 5
for $2. This offer is open to all students who are having pictures made
for the book. Everyone is urged to
take advantage of this opportunity.
The photos will be taken of the
Seniors this week only. It is for this
reason that it is necessary for prompt
arrival and payment, as the charge of
$1 is made with the photo.

among the manuscripts of the Huntington Library collection, in California.
Dr. Heltzel was also instrumental in
the translating of the document from
the original Latin form, and it was
with his permission that Dr. Hudson
addressed the group.
The manuscript wai written just
after Sidney's death during the English Renaissance by a London medical
doctor and Latin scholar, one Dr. Moffet. It was not written as a biography
but rather as an object lesson from
the man who wrote it to his young
nephew, Wm. Henry, later the Earl of
Pembroke, who was at the time just
entering Oxford, at the age of 14.
The manuscript is very important as
it contains the greatest praise ever
heaped on Sidney, and also gives many
details of his early life and of his fighting in Flanders, where he died, heretofore unknown. It especially commends
his valor in battle, holding him up
as a paragon of virtue and courage.
Although they wish to make this
valuable literature public, neither Dr.
Hudson nor his associate are yet satisfied with the Latin translation they
have made. After revision is made,
the document will be ready for publication.

Blue Jay Booters Battle
Randolph-Macon's Speed
Towson Teachers To Tie
Proves Too Much For Blue
On Last Play Ruled Void; Clisham Clinches
Eleven's Sturdy Defense Goal Scored
Spotlight With Outstanding Booting; Kephart
Tames "Towson Threat"
Virginians Win By 25 - 7 As
Bair And Paliscak
Shine
JAYS

SCORE

LATE

Graziano Tallies In Last
Quarter As Kahl And
Vickers Star
A fast, hard-charging aggregation,
wearing the brilliant yellow jerseys
of Randolph-Macon, suppressed a
at
Hopkins opposition
stubborn
Homewood Saturday, triumphing by
a count of 25-7.
Inspired by the superb running and
fine punting of their quarterback,
"Baby" Bair, the Virginia eleven
pushed over four well-earned touchdowns, thereby pulling out of what
was a disastrous slump.
Speed Too Much
The Blue Jays, despite their determination to maintain a perfect record against their erst-while foes,
could not cope with the speed of the
Randalph-Macon backfield. Their line
play around the center was practically
air-tight, but the visting team elected
to direct its attack around the ends.
However, it took a system of tricky
laterals, and some well-nigh perfect
blocking to make this offensive successful.
The Virginians' scoring was concentrated in the third and early fourth
quarters. "Baby" Bair's 65-yard demonstration of broken - field running
was the outstanding event of the
afternoon. Paliscak, who scored three
touchdowns, was the visiting team's
star.
Graziano Scores
Hopkins' only score came underway in the fourth period with Kahl
and Graziano doing all of the balltoting. Graziano veritably hurled himself across from the 1-yard line.
Randolph-Macon lost no time in
taking the opening Hopkins' kick-off
and driving the Jays back to their own
goal line. In the shadow of their
goal posts, the Blue team tightened
its defense and held for downs. Again
the Yellow-Jackets plowed ahead only
to be denied once more by inspired
resistance on the part of the Jays'
forward wall.
Randolph-Macon Tallies
But when the Jays kicked out of
danger, a lateraled runback set the
stage for the first tally for RandolphMacon. A sustained running and
passing attack earned the Jackets
their first six points. Poliscak hitting
the line for the score. The placement
was wide. The remainder of the first
quarter saw the Blue Jays fighting
hard to push over a touchdown and
being checked by an unpenetrable
visiting line.
The second period brought renewed hopes to the home-team rooters.
After dominating the play for a short
while, the Virginians were forced to
kick, the ball bouncing over the Hopkins goal line for a touchback. Taking
the ball on their own 20-yard line,
the Jays moved fifty yards in a sustained drive, with Graziano and Kahl
carrying the ball off tackle and around
the ends. The Blue line opened up
large holes for the backs to charge
through. But Randolph-Macon finally held for downs on their own 30yard line. The half ended with the
Yellow Jackets in possession of the
ball at midfield.
Jay Strategy Fails
The second half was all RandolphMacon. To start things, instead of
punting on fourth down while on
their own 30-yard line, Hopkins chose
to run the ball in an attempt to gain
a first down. This strategy failed,
and the visitors tok the ball on their
opponent's 30. From here the YellowJackets pushed to a first-down on the
20-yard marker, from which point
Paliscak again crossed the goal line.
The placement this time was good,
and the score stood at 13-0.
Randolph-Macon kickied off and
for a while it looked as if the hometeam were marching to a touchdown.
But once again the visitors tightened.
Bair and Paliscak combined their
running skill to add six more ponts
to their team's total. Paliscak again
bucked the line for the tally. The
conversion attempt failed. The score
stood 19-0.
Early in the last stanza, Greer
punted from deep in his own territory
to the Randolph-Macon 35-yard line.
Bair caught the ball and ran 65 yards

Johnnies Bag
Fourth In Row

The Blue Jay booters battled the
Towson Teachers to a scoreless tie
at Homewood last Friday.
Hopkins came close to a victory
when Bill Gough, playing right half
for the Jays, drew a penalty kick after
a foul by Towson. His boot struck
Goalie Hamilton and the ball bounded back into the playing field. Gough
followed up with another boot which
went into the goal. The referee, however, blew his whistle, after the goal
had been kicked, ruled that the period had ended just after the foul
kick and refused to allow the goal.
Despite the heavy winds that prevailed throughout the game, Clisham,
Jay full back, displayed some outstanding booting. His counter-wind
kicks carried with them the speed and
precision so peculiar to the professional back. Time and again, his welldirected punts had all but dented the
net only to be thwarted by the timely
interception of Goalie Hamilton.
Cecil Kephart, substituting at half
back for Phillips, who in turn was
shifted to the line, also is due worthy
praise for his successful humbling of
Smith, outstanding player for the
Towson Teachers in their previous
meet with the Blue Jays. According
to spectators, he literally "tied him
in a knot." Kephart played the "Towson Threat" close to the line and
never once yielded to his driving onslaught to force the ball into the center of the playing field.

The lack of scoring punch still persisted, however, and aside from the
disputed goal, the Jays were unable to
score.
The most serious set-back to the
Blue "Jays predicted progress this
season, has been the injuries suffered
by several of the more outstanding
performers.
Phillips, left half back and the most
outstanding performer of last season, has been suffering with a bad
ankle ever since the first scrimmage
this year. Bernheim, captain and
right full back, was making repid
strides as a defense performer when
he suffered a muscle injury to his
right leg. Briggs, center forward,
who as a newcome to the Johns Hopkins team, gave a convincing exhibition of offensive play, also is suffering -from a leg injury.
Coach Frank Dotterweich, however,
believes these handicaps will be overcome when the Hopkins entertains the
Blue Ridge Rooters at Homewood,
Saturday at 2.30 o'clock.
Although relatively little is known
concerning the booting ability of the
Mountaineers, nevertheless Coach
Dotterweich will strengthen his offensive line to the limit in order to
assure himself of a quick victory.
Kephart, as a reward for his -brilliant performance in Friday's game,
will share opening honors in the coming tilt.

Sportlight
Entered Hopkins as freshman in
'99 . . . While a student, he was instrumental in building up lacrosse
--in it's embryo form at Hopkins at
the time . . . played five years of varsity lacrosse--the last year as first
year man at the Medical School . . .
Was made a special ex-captain to the
four year rule which was just inaugurated in his senior year . . .
As youngster, played first lacrosse
game as fill-in at center for B.A.C.
to which team he was mascot . . .
Also, played sandlot football with
"Old Parks," together with Arthur
and Philip Poole of Princeton fame.
At Hopkins played ace hockey and
ran in the first relay team to beat
Penn . . . Also copped gymnastic
championship of University for two
years. . . .
Dr. Abercrombie, was President of
his Senior Class and likewise of the
Athletic Board in which he played a
important role in the organization of
the Athletic Association. . .
At present Dr. Abercrombie is the
Director of the University Physical
Education Department at which he
has become a well known campus
personality.
